awd_titl_txt: Mappings of real submanifolds in complex space, CR geometry, and analytic PDE
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to study geometric and analytic aspects of generic real submanifolds in complex manifolds (or, more generally, of manifolds with a CR-structure). Particular attention will be paid to the structure of mappings between such manifolds. Examples of generic manifolds include (smooth) boundaries of open subsets of complex Euclidian space. Important information about proper mappings between open sets can be gleaned from their restrictions to the boundary. Basic questions that will be investigated include the existence, uniqueness, and regularity of CR-mappings between given CR-manifolds, as well as geometric questions that arise in connection with this study. The objective is to gain a deeper understanding of mappings in CR-geometry, and their role in complex analysis and PDE. One part of the project will focus on these problems in the context of nontrivial CR-mappings of a Levi-nondegenerate hypersurface into another of higher dimension. The principal investigator expects that this research will lead to a better grasp of how the local CR-geometry of such hypersurfaces (which, in principle, is completely encoded in the Chern-Moser CR-curvature tensor) affects geometric properties of CR-mappings (e.g., various notions of nondegeneracy and rigidity). The principal investigator will also study geometric and analytic properties of CR-mappings between more general CR-manifolds. A particular analytic property of interest is that of finite jet determination. The equidimensional case is by now fairly well understood. The principal investigator intends to study the situation where the target manifold has a higher dimension than that of the source. This situation appears to be drastically different from the equidimensional one. The principal investigator anticipates that this study will involve the development of substantially new methods, which in turn will enhance our understanding of mappings into higher dimensional spaces.

The study of real submanifolds in complex manifolds is central to complex analysis and to other areas of mathematics and physics. In this research, tools from a wide range of areas such as real and complex analysis, partial differential equations, and algebraic geometry are used and further developed. The principal investigator is hopeful that the investigations carried out in this project will enhance our understanding of the geometry of real submanifolds and partial differential equations in complex space, which will benefit research in adjacent areas of mathematics as well as in areas of theoretical physics. He expects the project to provide interesting research topics for graduate students. The seminar activity that results from the project should prove stimulating for both students and other researchers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
One of the main motivations behind this research project is to better understand boundaries of complex manifolds. Many mathematical models of physical phenomena that arise in physics, chemistry, biology, and engineering rely on complex numbers, and more generally complex analysis. The models lead to the study of quantities, or functions, that depend on multiple variables that are allowed to take complex numbers.  The functions are often defined using complicated relations, or equations, that involve both the functions, their derivatives, and the variables on which they depend. The mathematical descriptions lead naturally to complex manifolds as the collection of states, or values, on which the functions are defined. An important phenomenon that arises for analytic functions on complex manifolds is that their behaviour are more or less completely determined by their behaviour near, or at the boundary of the complex manifold. Thus, understanding boundaries of complex manifolds is of fundamental importance, and the intellectual merit of this research project has been to further develop and expand on an already existing local theory of such boundaries called CR geometry. 

More specifically, the PI has investigated the local geometry of real submanifolds (such as boundaries of domains) embedded in complex manifolds, or more generally abstract manifolds with a CR structure. The main results can be summarized as follows:

1. Rigidity of embeddings of strictly pseudoconvex hypersurfaces. A basic question is to what extent the local CR geometry determines the possible embeddings of a given CR manifold. As a part of this research project, the PI has proved several differnt results along these lines. In one paper, a rigidity result is obtained for embeddings of one nondegenerate hyperquadric of signature l into another of signature l': If the signature difference l'-l is strictly bounded by the signature l, then the embedding is contained in an affine complex subspace of a dimension bounded from above by the sum of the source space and the signature difference. In another paper, this result is generalized to classes of "non-spherical" Levi nondegenerate hypersurfaces and their embeddings into hyperquadrics. A third paper along these lines proves that there are at most two different embeddings of a strictly pseudoconvex 5-dimensional hypersurfaces into the sphere of dimension 7, and in a fourth paper rigidity phenomena are studied within a certain class of pseudoellipsoids (as generalizations of spheres).

2.  Transversality of holomorphic mappings between CR manifolds. In a series of two papers, the PI completes an investigation of transversality properties of holomorphic mappings that send one CR manifold into another. Transversality is an important geometric property in many analytic problems. The basic question is what CR geometric properties of the source and target manifolds force every holomorphic mapping between them to be transversal? In one paper, the PI gives a fairly definite and optimal answer to this question in the equidimensional case, proving a conjecture on this topic that originated in work of Baouendi and Rothschild from the early 1990's. In the second paper, the PI considers the more difficult problem of considering holomorphic maps into a higher dimensional space. Here, a satisfactory answer if provided for mappings that are already assumed to be finite.

The broader impact of this research project includes training of PhD students and mentoring of postdoctoral scholars. The PI partially supported 3 PhD students, Andre Minor, Ravi Shroff, and Son Duong, on this grant, and all three finished their degrees with theses that were influenced by and related to the work in this project. While this grant was active, the PI also mentored a postdoc, Yuan Zhang, for 3 years at UCSD, and his former PhD student Jiri Lebl, who also spent a year as a postdoc at UCSD. The PI also organized several conferences and workshops, whose themes were related to the topic in the project. These conferences and workshops exposed young researcher to top researchers in the field, and generally provided venues for broader dissemination of results and ideas in the field. 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2016
Modified by: Peter Ebenfelt
